```{r setup, include=FALSE}

## This is your set up code chunk!

# Set chunk options
knitr::opts_chunk$set(warning = FALSE, message=FALSE)

# Get your libraries

library(tidyverse)
library(gridExtra)
library(knitr)
library(RGraphics)

# Set ggplot theme

mytheme = theme_bw() + theme(panel.grid.major = element_blank(), 
                             panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
                             axis.text=element_text(size=14),
                             axis.title.x=element_text(size=14,face="bold"),
                             axis.title.y=element_text(size=14, face="bold"),
                             plot.title=element_text(size=20, hjust = 0.5),
                             plot.margin= margin(t = 20, r = 20, b = 20, l = 20, unit = "pt"),
                             legend.position="none")
theme_set(mytheme)

# Load your data

load("BabyData.rda")

# Other set up (functions, variable manipulation, etc.)


```

# Why should I make my presentation in R?

* No more copying and pasting graphs into powerpoint or keynote.

* Great for data presentations and lab meetings where you need to show lots of graphs.

* Great for tutorials or labs where you want to show code and output.

* Maybe don't use this when you really really care about how your slides are laid out.

***

# Controlling your presentation

* There are three areas within the markdown that are important for the look and feel of your presentation.

+ In the regular text, you control headings, text styles and outlines using special characters (#,*,+ etc.)

* Within the code chunks

* Within the headers of each code chunk, where you specify what should appear in the final document.

***

# Arranging your text

1.  Hashtags can be used to add headers of various sizes

2.  Start lines with numerals for a numbered list, or use (*) for unnumbered lines

3.  End a line with two spaces to start a new paragraph.  

* See code for how to do:
+  *italics* 
+ **bold**
+ superscripts^2^
+ ~~strikethrough~~
+ [link](www.rstudio.com)

***

# Adding Graphs

```{r, fig.align='center'}

ggplot(BabyData, aes(x=Month, y=Weight)) + geom_point(color="seagreen3", size=5) + geom_line(color="seagreen3") +
  scale_y_continuous(limits=c(0, 14), breaks=seq(0,14,2)) + labs(y="Weight (pounds)", title="How large is Evie?")

```

***

# Two Graphs, Side by Side

```{r, fig.align='center', fig.width=12, fig.height=4}

Graph1 <- ggplot(BabyData, aes(x=Month, y=Weight)) + geom_point(color="seagreen3", size=5) + 
  geom_line(color="seagreen3") + scale_y_continuous(limits=c(0, 14), breaks=seq(0,14,2)) + 
  labs(y="Weight (pounds)", title="How large is Evie?")

Graph2 <- ggplot(BabyData, aes(x=Month, y=SleepLength)) + geom_point(color="purple", size=5) + 
  geom_line(color="purple") + scale_y_continuous(limits=c(0, 14), breaks=seq(0,14,2)) + 
  labs(y="Longest Sleep Duration", title="How much does Evie sleep?")

grid.arrange(Graph1, Graph2, ncol=2)

```

***

# Two Graphs, Side by Side, No code

```{r, fig.align='center', fig.width=12, fig.height=7, echo=FALSE}

Graph1 <- ggplot(BabyData, aes(x=Month, y=Weight)) + geom_point(color="seagreen3", size=5) + 
  geom_line(color="seagreen3") + scale_y_continuous(limits=c(0, 14), breaks=seq(0,14,2)) + 
  labs(y="Weight (pounds)", title="How large is Evie?")

Graph2 <- ggplot(BabyData, aes(x=Month, y=SleepLength)) + geom_point(color="purple", size=5) + 
  geom_line(color="purple") + scale_y_continuous(limits=c(0, 14), breaks=seq(0,14,2)) + 
  labs(y="Longest Sleep Duration", title="How much does Evie sleep?")

grid.arrange(Graph1, Graph2, ncol=2)

```

***

# I want to build in my graphs!

```{r, fig.align='center', fig.height=5}

# Build an empty plot
BuildGraph <- ggplot(BabyData, aes(x=Month, y=Weight)) + scale_y_continuous(limits=c(0, 14), breaks=seq(0,14,2)) + 
  labs(y="Weight (pounds)", title="How large is Evie?")

grid.arrange(BuildGraph)

```

***

# I want to build in my graphs!

```{r, fig.align='center', fig.height=5}

# Add onto your empty plot in a second slide
BuildGraph <- BuildGraph + 
  geom_point(color="seagreen3", size=5) + geom_line(color="seagreen3") 

grid.arrange(BuildGraph)

```

***

```{r, fig.align='center', fig.height=5}

# Text
text <- "\n\n\nI added this text using the RGraphics package, combined with grid.arrange. It's still a little buggy, but you can experiment"
p2 <- splitTextGrob(text)
# Arrange the plots on the same page
grid.arrange(BuildGraph, p2, ncol=2)


```

# Include Code and Output: {r, No extra arguments}

```{r}

test <- lm(Weight~Month, data=BabyData)
summary(test)

```
***

```{r, echo=FALSE}

summary(test)

```
